data.title: College Cost Statistics – Average Costs & University
data.meta_description: Find out the average cost of college in your state. Easily compare the cost of attendance at over 1,600 schools.
data.text:
The true cost of college includes more than tuition and books. Room and board, parking passes, and meal plans can all factor into your expenses.

What those fees add up to—and what you ultimately pay to pursue a degree—hinges on where you attend school. We’ve researched average annual expenses at over 1,600 colleges and universities throughout the U.S. Read on to find out how much college might cost you.

Average cost of college statistics by type

The following is the average cost of attendance by school type, including tuition and fees, room and board, books and supplies, transportation, and estimated miscellaneous expenses. All figures represent the 2023 – 2024 school year unless otherwise noted.

Private 4-Year Not-for-Profit: $60,420 (jump to full breakdown)

Public 4-Year Out-of-State: $46,730 (jump to full breakdown)

Public 4-Year In-State: $28,840 (jump to breakdown)

Public 2-Year In-District:​ $19,860 (jump to breakdown)

Private For-Profit: $15,740* (jump to full breakdown)

*Tuition and fees only for the 2022 – 2023 school year

Private 4-year not-for-profit colleges & universities

Cost of attendance

Tuition & fees: $41,540

Room & board: $14,650

Books & supplies: $1,250

Transportation: $1,100

Other expenses: $1,880

Total cost: $60,420

Rate of increase in price

Rate of tuition increase: 5.4%

Rate of tuition & fees and room & board increase: 5.2%

Average financial aid received

Grants & scholarships: $25,630 (for 2023 – 2024 school year)

Public 4-year out-of-state colleges & universities

Cost of attendance

Tuition & fees: $29,150

Room & board: $12,770

Books & supplies: $1,250

Transportation: $1,290

Other expenses: $2,270

Total cost: $46,730

Rate of increase in price

Rate of tuition increase: 3.2%

Rate of tuition & fees and room & board increase: 3.4%

Average financial aid received

Grants & scholarships: $8,530 (for 2023 – 2024 school year)

Public 4-year in-state colleges & universities

Cost of attendance

Tuition & fees: $11,260

Room & board: $12,770

Books & supplies: $1,250

Transportation: $1,290

Other expenses: $2,270

Total cost: $28,840

Rate of increase in price

Rate of tuition increase: 2.9%

Rate of tuition & fees and room & board increase: 3.4%

Average financial aid received

Grants & scholarships: $8,530 (for 2023 – 2024 school year)

Public 2-year in-district colleges & universities

Cost of attendance

Tuition & fees: $3,990

Room & board: $9,970

Books & supplies: $1,470

Transportation: $1,930

Other expenses: $2,500

Total cost: $19,860

Rate of increase in price

Rate of tuition increase: 3.4%

Rate of tuition & fees and room & board increase: 3.6%

Average financial aid received

Grants & scholarships: $4,320 (for 2023 – 2024 school year)

Private for-profit colleges & universities

Cost of attendance

Tuition & fees: $15,740

Average financial aid received

Grants & scholarships: $4,820 (2-year) – $7,210 (4-year) (for the 2021 – 2022 school year)

Note: Less data is available for for-profit colleges and universities as compared to the others listed above.

Cost of specific colleges & universities in the U.S.

To help you compare costs during the school selection process, we’ve aggregated data from the National Center of Education Statistics. In the tables below, you’ll see the average total cost for the 2023 – 2024 school year at 1,667 colleges and universities around the United States.

Schools are listed alphabetically by state, and we’ve included separate columns for in-state and out-of-state students. Remember that reported costs account for tuition and fees, books and supplies, room and board, and estimated miscellaneous expenses.

However, these costs don’t factor in scholarships, grants, or other forms of financial aid. The net price of some schools may be less depending on how much free financial aid the average student receives.

Final thoughts

While the cost of college continues to rise, it’s important for students to understand their financial aid options. Before you take out student loans, explore scholarship and grant programs. Here are other resources to consider:

Average dorm cost

Do hospitals help pay for nursing school?

Schools offering tuition breaks for law enforcement

Does the military pay for college?

If you do need to borrow money for school, make sure you borrow responsibly. Brief yourself on the average student debt burden, and research student loan repayment plans sooner rather than later.

Giving yourself a head start on your student loan payoff strategy may not seem necessary now, but in a few years’ time, you—and your bank account—will be glad you did.

Data sources
